\subsection{Accretion disk model of the broad band spectrum}

For the description of the accretion disk emission we use the model {\sc optxagnf} developed by Done
et al. (2012) for the purpose of modeling NLS1, and implemented in XSPEC (Arnaud 1996). This phenomenological model well represents the complexity of the disk emission. Bare disk in this model is seen for radii larger than $R_{cor}$, and the inner disk region is covered by the disk corona. The local disk emission is color-corrected using the approximations given in Done et al. (2012). Inside $R_{cor}$, part of the energy is dissipated in the corona. Two thermal Comptonization media are necessary. Low temperature Comptonization is necessary to model the soft X-ray excess. This soft Comptonization is described by the electron temperature, $T_e$, and the optical depth, $\tau$, and implemented in XSPEC as {\sc comptt} (Titarchuk 1994). The second Comptonization has to reproduce the power law emission which dominates above 2 keV. This high temperature component is described by {\sc nthcomp} (Zdziarski et al. 1996), and parameterized by the hard X-ray slope, $\Gamma$, and the fraction of energy, $f_{pl}$, dissipated in the hard X-ray emitting corona, while the temperature of the hot coronal phase is fixed at 100 keV. The soft part of the corona may physically correspond to an optically thick skin on the top of the disk, and it is likely strongly magnetized (R\' o\. za\' nska et al. 2015).

Input parameters of the model are the black hole mass, $M_{BH}$, black hole spin, $a$, bolometric Eddington ratio, $L/L_{\rm Edd}$, $R_{cor}$,  $T_e$, $\tau$, $\Gamma$, $f_{pl}$,  the comoving (proper) distance of the source, and redshift. 

\section{Fitting methods}
\label{sect:fitting}

The model contains numerous free parameters,  and 45 of those are normalizations of different starlight components in the STARLIGHT code. Since we use this special code for starlight fitting, based on very efficient Monte Carlo Markoff Chain method, while X-ray data fitting with XSPEC has also its complexity, we divided the fitting procedure in two parts which are done independently, and the global solution is obtained through iterations between the two parts.

We first model the optical/UV part. This approach has also the advantage of giving results directly comparable to Bian \& Huang (2010). 

In that part we (temporarily) replace the disk component with the power law, as in Bian \& Huang (2010). We subtract Fe II emission and Balmer continuum from the data, using a dense grid of the normalizations of these components, and then we run the  STARLIGHT code with a pre-set power law slope to get the starlight shape given by 45 normalizations of the components, the systematic stellar velocity, stellar velocity dispersion and the reddening. The resulting $\chi^2$  is used to select the best fit solution. Regions of the strong BLR emissions are masked and do not contribute to the fit quality.  The gap between the SDSS and HST data is masked as well, and the shift in the HST data is allowed.

Having the initial decomposition of the optical/UV spectrum, we subtract the starlight, Fe II and Balmer continuum from the original data. We are then left with the disk component. In principle, we could just use the power law from the best fit model as the disk representation in the optical/UV part but the power law is not a perfect representation of the disk shape due to the radius-dependent color correction. 

The number of data points is much higher in optical/UV band (5401) than in the X-ray band (109), despite masking the strong emission line regions. Without binning, this would lead to a strong dependence of disk fitting on the optical/UV part where the disk contribution is actually very minor in most part of the spectrum. We thus bin the optical/UV points representing the disk contribution, with the gaps retained, as in the optical/UV data fitting. Gaps are then ignored in the broad band fitting (including X-rays).  

For the errors in the resulting data points we take the statistical errors derived from the initial errors in the spectrum, but we also include the systematic errors. Binning reduces the statistical errors down to very small values. On the other hand, the disk component is formed by subtraction of the very complex model from the original data. Although the fit is generally reasonable, it is not perfect, and some systematic patterns are clearly visible in the residuals. They bias the small expected disk contribution significantly. We thus used additional systematic error ingredient in the disk component fitting procedure. In order to account for generally higher data quality in the optical band and lower in the UV part, we assumed that this systematic error in the original data set is of the type $A(1000/\lambda)$. The normalization A was determined by assumption that the best fit of the full model described above should give the reduced $\chi^2$ equal 1 (without it, it is about 1.3). In this way we obtained the value $A = 2.0 \times 10^{-16}$ erg s$^{-1}$ \AA$^{-1}$. When subsequently we bin the data, the statistical error is reduced, but we retain this systematic error for the disk component.

We then combine the resulting opt/UV spectrum representing the disk emission with long XMM observation and perform the disk fitting using the model {\sc optxagnf} from XSPEC package. The best fit accretion disk model is again selected by minimizing the $\chi^2$. From this broad band fit we obtain new approximation for the disk contribution to the optical/UV band which is not of a power law shape, mostly due to the color-correction to the disk emission.

With this new disk contribution we return to the starlight and other components fitting. This time we do not allow for any arbitrary power law in STARLIGHT code, as at the first stage, but we subtract the new disk emission from the data. We calculate a grid of data sets again for various normalizations of the Fe II and BC component, and runnning STARLIGHT code for each of them we again choose the solution with the lowest $\chi^2$  as the best one.

We can repeat such iterations several times but we found that the second iteration is actually quite satisfactory, taking into account the fitting accuracy.

Following the procedure described in Sect.~\ref{sect:fitting} we present here the results of the fitting of all components: starlight, BC, Fe II and accretion disk to the broad band optical/UV/X-ray data.

This value slightly differs from the value given by NED (z = 0.042443) and the value of z = 0.043 adopted by Bian \& Huang (2010). The best fit solution was quite close to the solution found by Bian \& Huang (2010). \subsection{Disk fitting to opt/UV/X-ray data}

Having the contribution of the starlight, Fe II and Balmer continuum we can determine the disk contribution more accurately by subtracting these components from the original data.  
We combine the resulting opt/UV spectrum representing the disk emission with long XMM observation and perform
the disk fitting using the model {\sc optxagnf} from XSPEC package (Arnaud 1996). The long XMM-Newton observation is taken from Middleton et al. (2011) (OBSID: 0506440101, with full exposure $\sim$ 94 ks).
The disk model {\sc optxagnf} is described in detailed in Sect. 3.4. Our base model to fit the broad band continuum reads {\sc tbabs*optxagnf}, in which the Galactic value $N_{\rm H}$ of {\sc tbabs} is $1.47 \times 10^{20}$ $\rm cm^{-2}$. The input parameters of the model for the disk components are the black hole mass, $M_{\odot}\le M_{\rm BH} \le 10^9M_{\odot}$, black hole spin, $0.0 \le a \le 0.998$, bolometric Eddington ratio, $-10 \le \rm log$ $L/L_{\rm Edd} \le 2$, coronal radius $1 \le r_{\rm cor} \le 100$ in units of $r_g = G M/c^2$, the outer radius of the disk $3\le \rm log$ $r_{\rm out}\le 7$. The inclination angle in the {\sc optxagnf} model is fixed with $60^{\circ}$, although inclination angle could change the normalization by a factor $\sim$ 2. Moreover, both the soft and hard Comptonization, i.e., electron temperature $T_{\rm e}$, optical depth of the soft Comptonization component $\tau$, spectral index of the hard Comptonization component $\Gamma$,  are fixed with the values derived from X-ray spectrum fitting alone by Middleton et al. (2011), except that the input parameter, $0 \le f_{\rm pl} \le 1$, is a free parameter in our fitting representing the fraction of the energy emitted in the hard Comptonization component.
 
We cannot fit all the parameter uniquely, so we consider in detail the three different estimates of the black hole mass coming from the QPO estimates, and we fit the broad band spectrum with respective given $M_{\rm BH}$, seperately. The results are summarized in Table~\ref{tab:optagn_fitting} and plotted in Fig.~\ref{fig:optagnfitting}. As for $M_{\rm BH}=1.0\times 10^7 M_{\odot}$, $6.9\times 10^6 M_{\odot}$, the broad band continuum can be fitted well with $\chi^2/\rm dof=131.76/132~(1.00), 127.89/132~(0.97)$. The black hole spins $a$ and the outer radius peg at their boundaries with $a=0.998$, and $\rm log$ $r_{\rm out}=3$, respectively. However, small black hole mass $M_{\rm BH}=4.0 \times 10^5 M_{\odot}$ does not fit the data points at all, which is manifested that the optical model continuum is a factor 3 smaller than the optical observed continuum. Therefore, we need to clarify if this discrepancy could be due to the limit range of the {\sc optxagnf} parameters (e.g. non-negative values of the spin) or the small value of black hole mass. The normalization of the optical luminosity $N \propto (M_{\rm BH}\dot{M})^{2/3}=[M_{\rm BH}\cdot 10^{\rm logL/L_{\rm Edd}}\cdot L_{\rm Edd}/(\eta c^2)]^{2/3}$ (Davis \& Laor 2011), where $L_{\rm Edd}=1.26 \times 10^{38}M_{\rm BH}/M_{\odot}\ \rm erg/s$, the efficiency $\eta$ can be derived as a function of the spin (Novikov \& Thorne 1973; You et al 2015). In Table~\ref{tab:optagn_fitting}, for $\rm logM_{\rm BH,1}/M_{\odot}=7$, $\rm logL_{1}/L_{\rm Edd,1}=-0.77$ and $\eta_{1}=0.32$ for $a=0.998$; for $\rm logM_{\rm BH,2}/M_{\odot}=5.6$, $\rm logL_{2}/L_{\rm Edd,2}=0.51$. Therefore, the ratio of the normalization of the optical luminosity between the two black hole masses can be approximated with $[(M_{\rm BH,1}/M_{\rm BH,2})^2\cdot 10^{\rm logL_{1}/L_{\rm Edd,1}-\rm logL_{2}/L_{\rm Edd,2}}\cdot (\eta_{2}/\eta_{1})]^{2/3}=[32.8(\eta_{2}/\eta_{1})]^{2/3}$. If we assume  $a=-1.0$ for $\rm logM_{\rm BH,2}/M_{\odot}=5.6$, $\eta_{2}=0.038$, then the normalization ratio is about 2.5. So even a counter-rotating black hole with $a=-1.0$ in the model cannot fit the observed spectrum. This simple argument, based on the total energetics, shows that the small black hole mass is unable to bring a consistent fit for optical/UV and X-ray band, independently from any possible limitations of the adopted model. The minimum mass, acceptable for the model, for a counter-rotating disk is thus $1.2 \times 10^6 M_{\odot}$. If we relax the assumption of the inclination angle of 60 deg, built into the model, and we replace it with the top view ($i = 0$ deg) the minimum (but also the maximum) black hole mass become lower by a factor of ${\sqrt 2}$. Thus, the absolute minimum for the mass in this method is $8.5 \times 10^5 M_{\odot}$.

\subsection{Second stage opt/UV fitting}

We chose the solution for the black hole mass $M = 6.9 \times 10^6 M_{\odot}$ for a detailed discussion in this section. The corresponding results of model fitting are plotted in Fig.~\ref{fig:optagnfit2}. The solution for the mass $M = 1.0 \times 10^7 M_{\odot}$ gives very similar results for the starlight properties.


The shape of the disk component resulting from broad band fits, refered to as ``agn'', is clearly different from a power law. We thus made an excercise by retaining all other parameters (Fe II shape and normalization, BC normalization and the correction factor for grey-shifting the HST data) and simply replaced the power law with a new {\sl agn} shape and normalization. The new fit from the STARLIGHT code shows an immediate improvement of the $\chi^2$ (see Table~\ref{table:FirstStage}). We then allowed all the normalizations to vary, we also included the UV Fe II template from Vestergaard \& Wilkes (2001) below 2500 \AA. The results are given in the last line of Table~\ref{table:FirstStage}. \subsection{Spectral features in absorption}

The decomposition of the optical/UV spectrum into the disk and starlight depends on the description of the disk model. Formal solution with a blue power law is better in $\chi^2$ term (see the first and the last lines in Table~\ref{table:FirstStage}. Therefore, we take a closer look at individual spectral features in order to see which of the two models provide better representation of the data. 

Unfortunately, the starlight contamination in an AGN is not easy to determine just from the individual absorption features since some of the usual starlight signatures in the form of absorption lines are filled up with broader emission lines from the BLR. We first checked directly in the data whether any absorption features are actually seen in our object. We used the features recommended by Cid Fernandes et al. (1998). 

We searched for these features in the available spectra. The enlarged spectra in the promising wavelength range are shown in Fig.~\ref{fig:absorption}. We did not include the Ca II K + H$\epsilon$ band $\lambda\lambda$3952-3988 since it is strongly contaminated by emission, and the Na I region  $\lambda\lambda$5880-5914 as there is no visible spectral feature. We see some traces of absorption in four bands. The Ca II K is the most clear case, additionally located in the bluer part of the spectrum. Here we see that the complex but physically justified model of the accretion disk contribution reproduces well the depth of the feature while the blue power law solution (the first line in Table~\ref{table:FirstStage}) gives too shallow absorption feature meaning that the disk contribution is overestimated in this model. Other three features are not so deep, and both fits are comparable although formally they differ by a factor of 2 in the derived stellar dispersion value. This is because the data as well as input models are marginal for the purpose of the stellar dispersion measurement.

\section{Black hole mass from the X-ray variability}

\subsection{Method}

\subsection{Accretion disk model of the broad band spectrum}

For the description of the accretion disk emission we use the model {\sc optxagnf} developed by Done
et al. (2012) for the purpose of modeling NLS1, and implemented in XSPEC (Arnaud 1996). This phenomenological model well represents the complexity of the disk emission. Bare disk in this model is seen for radii larger than $R_{cor}$, and the inner disk region is covered by the disk corona. The local disk emission is color-corrected using the approximations given in Done et al. (2012). Inside $R_{cor}$, part of the energy is dissipated in the corona. Two thermal Comptonization media are necessary. Low temperature Comptonization is necessary to model the soft X-ray excess. This soft Comptonization is described by the electron temperature, $T_e$, and the optical depth, $\tau$, and implemented in XSPEC as {\sc comptt} (Titarchuk 1994). The second Comptonization has to reproduce the power law emission which dominates above 2 keV. This high temperature component is described by {\sc nthcomp} (Zdziarski et al. 1996), and parameterized by the hard X-ray slope, $\Gamma$, and the fraction of energy, $f_{pl}$, dissipated in the hard X-ray emitting corona, while the temperature of the hot coronal phase is fixed at 100 keV. The soft part of the corona may physically correspond to an optically thick skin on the top of the disk, and it is likely strongly magnetized (R\' o\. za\' nska et al. 2015).

Input parameters of the model are the black hole mass, $M_{BH}$, black hole spin, $a$, bolometric Eddington ratio, $L/L_{\rm Edd}$, $R_{cor}$,  $T_e$, $\tau$, $\Gamma$, $f_{pl}$,  the comoving (proper) distance of the source, and redshift. 

\section{Fitting methods}
\label{sect:fitting}

The model contains numerous free parameters,  and 45 of those are normalizations of different starlight components in the STARLIGHT code. Since we use this special code for starlight fitting, based on very efficient Monte Carlo Markoff Chain method, while X-ray data fitting with XSPEC has also its complexity, we divided the fitting procedure in two parts which are done independently, and the global solution is obtained through iterations between the two parts.

We first model the optical/UV part. This approach has also the advantage of giving results directly comparable to Bian \& Huang (2010). 

In that part we (temporarily) replace the disk component with the power law, as in Bian \& Huang (2010). We subtract Fe II emission and Balmer continuum from the data, using a dense grid of the normalizations of these components, and then we run the  STARLIGHT code with a pre-set power law slope to get the starlight shape given by 45 normalizations of the components, the systematic stellar velocity, stellar velocity dispersion and the reddening. The resulting $\chi^2$  is used to select the best fit solution. Regions of the strong BLR emissions are masked and do not contribute to the fit quality.  The gap between the SDSS and HST data is masked as well, and the shift in the HST data is allowed.

Having the initial decomposition of the optical/UV spectrum, we subtract the starlight, Fe II and Balmer continuum from the original data. We are then left with the disk component. In principle, we could just use the power law from the best fit model as the disk representation in the optical/UV part but the power law is not a perfect representation of the disk shape due to the radius-dependent color correction. 

The number of data points is much higher in optical/UV band (5401) than in the X-ray band (109), despite masking the strong emission line regions. Without binning, this would lead to a strong dependence of disk fitting on the optical/UV part where the disk contribution is actually very minor in most part of the spectrum. We thus bin the optical/UV points representing the disk contribution, with the gaps retained, as in the optical/UV data fitting. Gaps are then ignored in the broad band fitting (including X-rays).  

For the errors in the resulting data points we take the statistical errors derived from the initial errors in the spectrum, but we also include the systematic errors. Binning reduces the statistical errors down to very small values. On the other hand, the disk component is formed by subtraction of the very complex model from the original data. Although the fit is generally reasonable, it is not perfect, and some systematic patterns are clearly visible in the residuals. They bias the small expected disk contribution significantly. We thus used additional systematic error ingredient in the disk component fitting procedure. In order to account for generally higher data quality in the optical band and lower in the UV part, we assumed that this systematic error in the original data set is of the type $A(1000/\lambda)$. The normalization A was determined by assumption that the best fit of the full model described above should give the reduced $\chi^2$ equal 1 (without it, it is about 1.3). In this way we obtained the value $A = 2.0 \times 10^{-16}$ erg s$^{-1}$ \AA$^{-1}$. When subsequently we bin the data, the statistical error is reduced, but we retain this systematic error for the disk component.

We then combine the resulting opt/UV spectrum representing the disk emission with long XMM observation and perform the disk fitting using the model {\sc optxagnf} from XSPEC package. The best fit accretion disk model is again selected by minimizing the $\chi^2$. From this broad band fit we obtain new approximation for the disk contribution to the optical/UV band which is not of a power law shape, mostly due to the color-correction to the disk emission.

With this new disk contribution we return to the starlight and other components fitting. This time we do not allow for any arbitrary power law in STARLIGHT code, as at the first stage, but we subtract the new disk emission from the data. We calculate a grid of data sets again for various normalizations of the Fe II and BC component, and runnning STARLIGHT code for each of them we again choose the solution with the lowest $\chi^2$  as the best one.

We can repeat such iterations several times but we found that the second iteration is actually quite satisfactory, taking into account the fitting accuracy.

\subsection{Disk fitting to opt/UV/X-ray data}

Having the contribution of the starlight, Fe II and Balmer continuum we can determine the disk contribution more accurately by subtracting these components from the original data.  
We combine the resulting opt/UV spectrum representing the disk emission with long XMM observation and perform
the disk fitting using the model {\sc optxagnf} from XSPEC package (Arnaud 1996). The long XMM-Newton observation is taken from Middleton et al. (2011) (OBSID: 0506440101, with full exposure $\sim$ 94 ks).
The disk model {\sc optxagnf} is described in detailed in Sect. 3.4. Our base model to fit the broad band continuum reads {\sc tbabs*optxagnf}, in which the Galactic value $N_{\rm H}$ of {\sc tbabs} is $1.47 \times 10^{20}$ $\rm cm^{-2}$. The input parameters of the model for the disk components are the black hole mass, $M_{\odot}\le M_{\rm BH} \le 10^9M_{\odot}$, black hole spin, $0.0 \le a \le 0.998$, bolometric Eddington ratio, $-10 \le \rm log$ $L/L_{\rm Edd} \le 2$, coronal radius $1 \le r_{\rm cor} \le 100$ in units of $r_g = G M/c^2$, the outer radius of the disk $3\le \rm log$ $r_{\rm out}\le 7$. The inclination angle in the {\sc optxagnf} model is fixed with $60^{\circ}$, although inclination angle could change the normalization by a factor $\sim$ 2. Moreover, both the soft and hard Comptonization, i.e., electron temperature $T_{\rm e}$, optical depth of the soft Comptonization component $\tau$, spectral index of the hard Comptonization component $\Gamma$,  are fixed with the values derived from X-ray spectrum fitting alone by Middleton et al. (2011), except that the input parameter, $0 \le f_{\rm pl} \le 1$, is a free parameter in our fitting representing the fraction of the energy emitted in the hard Comptonization component.
 
We cannot fit all the parameter uniquely, so we consider in detail the three different estimates of the black hole mass coming from the QPO estimates, and we fit the broad band spectrum with respective given $M_{\rm BH}$, seperately. The results are summarized in Table~\ref{tab:optagn_fitting} and plotted in Fig.~\ref{fig:optagnfitting}. As for $M_{\rm BH}=1.0\times 10^7 M_{\odot}$, $6.9\times 10^6 M_{\odot}$, the broad band continuum can be fitted well with $\chi^2/\rm dof=131.76/132~(1.00), 127.89/132~(0.97)$. The black hole spins $a$ and the outer radius peg at their boundaries with $a=0.998$, and $\rm log$ $r_{\rm out}=3$, respectively. However, small black hole mass $M_{\rm BH}=4.0 \times 10^5 M_{\odot}$ does not fit the data points at all, which is manifested that the optical model continuum is a factor 3 smaller than the optical observed continuum. Therefore, we need to clarify if this discrepancy could be due to the limit range of the {\sc optxagnf} parameters (e.g. non-negative values of the spin) or the small value of black hole mass. The normalization of the optical luminosity $N \propto (M_{\rm BH}\dot{M})^{2/3}=[M_{\rm BH}\cdot 10^{\rm logL/L_{\rm Edd}}\cdot L_{\rm Edd}/(\eta c^2)]^{2/3}$ (Davis \& Laor 2011), where $L_{\rm Edd}=1.26 \times 10^{38}M_{\rm BH}/M_{\odot}\ \rm erg/s$, the efficiency $\eta$ can be derived as a function of the spin (Novikov \& Thorne 1973; You et al 2015). In Table~\ref{tab:optagn_fitting}, for $\rm logM_{\rm BH,1}/M_{\odot}=7$, $\rm logL_{1}/L_{\rm Edd,1}=-0.77$ and $\eta_{1}=0.32$ for $a=0.998$; for $\rm logM_{\rm BH,2}/M_{\odot}=5.6$, $\rm logL_{2}/L_{\rm Edd,2}=0.51$. Therefore, the ratio of the normalization of the optical luminosity between the two black hole masses can be approximated with $[(M_{\rm BH,1}/M_{\rm BH,2})^2\cdot 10^{\rm logL_{1}/L_{\rm Edd,1}-\rm logL_{2}/L_{\rm Edd,2}}\cdot (\eta_{2}/\eta_{1})]^{2/3}=[32.8(\eta_{2}/\eta_{1})]^{2/3}$. If we assume  $a=-1.0$ for $\rm logM_{\rm BH,2}/M_{\odot}=5.6$, $\eta_{2}=0.038$, then the normalization ratio is about 2.5. So even a counter-rotating black hole with $a=-1.0$ in the model cannot fit the observed spectrum. This simple argument, based on the total energetics, shows that the small black hole mass is unable to bring a consistent fit for optical/UV and X-ray band, independently from any possible limitations of the adopted model. The minimum mass, acceptable for the model, for a counter-rotating disk is thus $1.2 \times 10^6 M_{\odot}$. If we relax the assumption of the inclination angle of 60 deg, built into the model, and we replace it with the top view ($i = 0$ deg) the minimum (but also the maximum) black hole mass become lower by a factor of ${\sqrt 2}$. Thus, the absolute minimum for the mass in this method is $8.5 \times 10^5 M_{\odot}$.

averaging described above (used also by Nikolajuk et al. 2009) gives smaller weight to such measurements. The error of the mass is
determined from the dispersion of the individual measurements. 



\subsection{Results}

The value of the black hole mass obtained from the X-ray excess variance is $(4.4 \pm 0.6) \times 10^5 M_{\odot}$, if the correction by a factor 20 is adopted, and the value of $(8.8 \pm 1.3) \times 10^6 M_{\odot}$, if no additional correction is applied. Since RE J1034+396 is a Narrow Line Seyfert 1, the first determination should be more appropriate. On the other hand, we can say in a more conservative way that the true mass from X-ray variability should be between these two values.

\section{Discussion}

In this paper we modeled the broad optical/UV/X-ray band of the spectrum of an exceptional Narrow Line Seyfert 1 galaxy RE J1034+396. The optical/UV part of the spectrum is strongly dominated by starlight emission. This is nicely consistent with no polarization detected in the optical band by Breeveld \& Puchnarewicz (1998). Two separate stellar populations are clearly seen, as obtained before by Bian \& Huang (2010) at the basis of the optical data analysis alone. However, the additional use of HST and X-ray data changes the fit quantitatively.

\subsection{Black hole mass}

We used several methods to determine the black hole mass in this source. The summary of the results is shown in Fig.~\ref{fig:mas_summary}. Lines shows acceptable ranges, where additional parameters are strongly involved, and points show individual measurements. 

Clearly, not all these methods give results which can be accomodated in a single most favorable result. The black hole mass measurements based on estimates on the stellar dispersion and O[III] are inconsistent with all the others. The measurement of the stellar dispersion with the SDSS data is not, in our opinion, highly reliable since the dispersion requested by the fitting changes strongly with the disk description. The measured velocity dispersion, here given as 136 km s$^{-1}$, may be by a factor of 2 lower, implying the mass lower by a factor of 16. On the other hand, the measurement based on O[III] should be quite precise. This value implies much higher bulge mass than the value expected from the standard relation between the bulge and the central black hole. RE J1034+396 belongs to NLS1 class, and there is a on-going discussion whether NLS1 galaxies follow the standard relation or lag behind in their evolution, being still at the stage of rapid black hole growth (see e.g. Mathur et al. 2001; Woo et al. 2015). The issue is additionally complicated by the rotational contamination of the stellar features (Woo et al. 2015).  

Also interpretation of the QPO as Low Frequency QPO is definitively inconsistent with other measurements. Thus High Frequency QPO interpretation is clearly favored, and both values are consistent with broad band fitting. The formal fit is somewhat better for lower value, corresponding to 2 times the fundamental frequency. It is interesting to note that in both cases the black hole spin has to be high, close to the maximally rotating solution. The object does not have a radio detection, and does not show any other imprints of the presence of a jet. On the other hand, there is no firm theory of QPO (see e.g. Czerny et al. 2010, Czerny \& Das 2011, Hu et al. 2014, Alston et al. 2015 and the references therein). If we try to connect the QPO just to the Keplerian frequency at the innermost stable circular orbit (see e.g. Lei et al. 2015) we will obtain a broad range of possible mass, $ 6.64 \le \log M_{BH} \le 7.69$ values since the black hole spin in our fitting is unconstrained.  

The black hole mass from higher HF QPO is marginally inconsistent with the range of masses implied by X-ray variability, while the mass derived from the lower HF QPO value is well consistent with X-ray variability. The caveat is, however, that to have the large mass tail implied by the X-ray variability we had to use the standard coefficient connecting the black mass with the X-ray excess variance instead of a coefficient appropriate for NLS1. Optical lines of RE J1034+369 are very narrow, below 1000 km s$^{-1}$, so the object does not seem to be a boundary case. 

The black hole masses based on the FWHM of H$\beta$ and Mg II are consistent with each other, but much lower ($\sim 10^6 M_{\odot}$) than the masses implied by HF QPO. Such small masses imply super-Eddington luminosities since the bolometric luminosity of the source corresponds to the value of the black hole mass  $ 2\sim 10^6 M_{\odot}$. Such a low value would be really consistent with expectations based on X-ray variability. Broad band fitting can also give consistent results if very low value of the spin, close to zero, is assumed. However, in this case the QPO phenomenon has no proper mode identification. It is difficult to assess at present the flexibility in the mass values given by Gierlinski et al. (2008). These values come directly from the relation for the fundamental frequency $f_0 = 931 (M/M_{\odot})^{-1}$ Hz (Remillard \& McClintock 2006) coming from three sources XTE J1550â564, GRO J1655â40,
and GRS 1915+105. All of them are microquasars, with black hole spin covering a broad range (XTE J1550â564, $a \sim 0.5$, Steiner et al. 2011; GRS 1915+105, $a \sim 0.95$ (Fragos \& McClintock 2015, You et al. 2015); GRO J1655â40, $ a \sim 0.3$, Motta et al. 2014). The masses of these sources are also determined with some errors, affecting the scaling. However, it is rather unlikely that the error is by an order of magnitude. Additionally, with small mass value for RE J1034+396, the discrepancy between the black hole mass and the bulge mass, becomes even more profound.

This discussion shows that, despite many efforts, the black hole mass determination in extreme sources remains a challenge.     

\subsection{Dust component}

Too shallow slope of the power law found by Bian \& Huang (2010) may be related to the presence of the hot dust emission in the near-IR. The presence of the hot dust in this source has also been postulated by Breevald \& Puchnarewicz (1998), at the basis of detection of highly ionized iron e.g. [Fe XI]$\lambda$7892. We did not include such component in our fitting since the model is already quite complex. 

\subsection{Starlight}

In this source the properties of the starlight are exceptionally well measured due to very low contribution of the disk to optical/UV band. It is interesting to note the presence of two populations although the details depend on the disk model, so the young population in Bian \& Huang (2010) is much younger ($\sim$ 10 Myr) than in our solution ($\sim$ 100 Myr). RE J1034+369 is not a starburst galaxy so this kind of a starlight can be treated as characteristic for all AGN, including quasars. Frequently, the stellar contamination is modeled using only older stellar population but this may overestimate the disk contribution at shorter wavelengths. This is particularly important in extremely blue sources like a quasar PG1426+015 (Watson et al. 2008).
